bioghist.p: Thomas Summerville Stewart (d. 1949) was curator of the Microscopical Department of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1895 and received his M.D. from the same institution in 1904. In the field of medicine, his main interest was in the x-ray. He was among the first to experiment with its varous uses. In the latter half of his life, he focused on microscopy and photo micrography. He was a member of the American Microscopical Society, a fellow of the Royal Microscopical Society, and vice president and treasurer of the Leidy Microscopical Society.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to microscopes and microscopy collected by Thomas S. Stewart. Microscope and lens manufacturers and supplies represented in the collection include Bausch and Lomb, Ernst Leitz, Inc., Arthur H. Thomas Company, Charles Lentz and Sons, and Williams, Brown, and Earle. Materials include: price lists and catalogs for microscopes and lenses; printed matter from the New York Microscopical Society and the Leidy Microscopical Club; a series of microscopic preparations on human anatomy (3 sets of 10); and prints of microphotographs. The collection also includes a handwritten manuscript of an article by Thomas C. Stewart entitled "Photo Micrography," and the text of a talk he gave at the Academy in 1941 on the history and use of the microscope. There is a small batch of correspondence of Thomas C. Stewart, related to the disposition of his father's microscope collection.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
